955.05   Establishment of curbside program.
955.06   Collection standards.
955.07   Source separation and collection of designated recyclables.
955.08   Establishment of leaf and yard waste facility.
955.09   Mandatory source separation of leaves and yard waste.
955.10   Mandatory commercial and institutional source-separation program.
955.11   Prohibited acts.
955.12   Non-collection of solid waste contaminated by designated recyclables.
955.13   Scavengers.
955.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
West Virginia Recycling Programs - see W.Va. Code Art. 20-11
   955.01  FINDINGS AND PURPOSE.
   The West Virginia Legislature has enacted Senate Bill Number 18, 1991, (The
West Virginia Recycling Act, West Virginia Code 20-11-1 ET SEQ) stipulating
that each municipality has the authority and duty to assure proper and adequate
transportation, collection, and storage of municipal waste which is generated
or present within its boundaries and to adopt and implement programs for the
collection and recycling of municipal solid waste or source-separated
recyclable materials. (Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.02 PURPOSE AND GOALS .
   Council finds that the reduction of the amount of solid waste and
conservation of recyclable materials is an important public concern and is
necessary to implement the requirements of the West Virginia Recycling Act.
Recycling of waste materials will minimize the adverse environmental effects of
land filling, decrease waste flow to landfill sites, conserve existing landfill
space, facilitate the implementation and operation of other forms of resource
recovery called for by the West Virginia Recycling Act, conserve natural
resources, and reduce the cost of solid waste disposal generally. The promotion
and use of goods which facilitate recycling will further serve the same
purposes by encouraging and facilitating recycling. The purpose of this article
is to regulate and control the collection, disposal and transportation of
recyclable materials whether collected by City personnel or by private haulers
and to mandate the separation and recycling of certain specified waste
materials. The City of Martinsburg will endeavor to comply with the West
Virginia State mandated goals for recycling of municipal solid waste generated
within City limits in the amount of 20% by January 1, 1994; 30% by January 1,
2000; and 50% by January 1, 2010.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.03 RESPONSIBLE AGENT .
   (a)   The City Council shall be responsible for all aspects of the Recycling
Program within the City.
   (b)   The City Council shall have the power and duty to:
      (1)   Provide public recyclable material collection, storage,
transportation and marketing service and/or approve and regulate the
establishment, maintenance and operation of private recyclable material
collection, storage, transportation, and marketing services and sites.
      (2)   Adopt, issue and enforce such rules and standards as are necessary
to implement and carry out the intent of this article.
      (3)   Issue warning notices and initiate proceedings against violators of
this article.
      (4)   Investigate all complaints made by either the public or any
contractor.
      (5)   Inspect all aspects of recyclable collection, storage and
marketing, including but not limited to equipment. containers, facilities,
books, and records.
      (6)   Designate an agent to enforce this article. (Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-
3-93.)
   955.04 DEFINITIONS .
   (a)   "Aluminum" shall mean all products made of aluminum including aluminum
cans, foil, wrappers, containers for prepared dinners and similar type
aluminum.
   (b)   "Cans" shall mean containers comprised of aluminum, tin, steel or a
combination thereof that have been approved for recycling by the Martinsburg
City Council.
      (1)   Includes, but not limited to: Cans formerly containing such
substances as vegetables, meats, fruits, juices, or other similar food storage
containers constructed of materials listed above.
      (2)   Does not include: Aerosol cans, hazardous cleaning substances,
automotive supply cans (eg. transmission fluids, motor oils, etc.), and other
similar containers.
   (c)   "Cardboard" shall mean all clean corrugated cardboard constructed of
two pieces of paper with a corrugated center normally used for packing,
mailing, shipping or containerizing goods, merchandise or other material, but
"excluding" plastic, foam, or wax coated or soiled cardboard such as cereal
boxes, milk cartons, shoe boxes and other similarly constructed items.
   (d)   "Co-mingled" shall mean source separated, non-putrescible recyclable
materials that have been mixed at the source of generation (i.e., placed in the
same container).
   (e)   "Contractor" shall mean a person or company designated by the City
Council to collect, transport, and market recyclables.
   (f)   "Designated Recyclable Materials" shall mean those recyclable
materials to be source separated within the City. The term includes, but is not
limited to, glass, cans, plastic bottles, newspaper, bi-metals, aluminum, white
office paper, cardboard, mixed paper, white goods, scrap metal, used motor oil,
anti-freeze, yard waste, and tires.
   (h) "Disposition” or "disposition of designated recyclable materials" shall
mean the transportation, placement, or arrangement of designated recyclable
materials for all possible end uses "except" disposal as solid waste.
   (i)   "Glass" shall mean all products made from silica or sand, soda ash and
limestone, the product being either transparent or translucent having been used
for packaging or bottling of various matter. Glass shall not include crystal,
ceramics, lightbulbs, and window plate, laminated, wired, pyrex or mirrored
glass.
   (j) "High-Grade office paper" shall include paper items generated by offices
and/or commercial entities. This may include white computer paper, white copier
paper, white typing paper, white letterhead paper, white note pad paper, and
other similar office paper.
   (k)   "Leaf and Yard Waste Facility" shall mean a drop-off point or area
designated by the City Council where leaves, grass clippings, tree trimmings,
brush, and garden residue shall be delivered for processing.
   (1)   "Municipality" shall mean the City of Martinsburg located within the
County of Berkeley, West Virginia.
   (m)   "Newspaper" shall mean any ground wood type paper used for newsprint.
   (n)   "Person" shall mean any individual, firm, partnership. corporation,
association, cooperative enterprise, trust, municipal authority, federal
institution or agency, state institution or agency, municipality, public and
private schools and educational facilities, other governmental agency or any
other entity or any group of such persons which is recognized by law. In any
provisions of this article prescribing a fine, penalty, or imprisonment, the
term "person" shall include the officers and directors of a corporation or
other legal entity having officers and directors.
   (o)   "Pick-Up Point" shall mean a location designated by the City Council
where recyclables are to be placed for receipt by the City and/or the
Contractor.
   (p)   "Plastic" shall mean any material made from any of a group of
synthetics containing polyethylene terephthalate such as plastic soda bottles,
milk and water jugs which also includes high density polyethylene (HDPE) such
as milk and water jugs and similar type juice jugs, bleach and detergent
bottles etc.
   (q)   "Recyclable Material" shall mean a material that would otherwise
become solid waste, that can be collected, separated or processed, and returned
to the economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products.
   (r)   "Recycling" shall mean any process whereby materials would otherwise
become solid waste, are collected, separated or processed, and returned to the
economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products.
   (s)   "Recycling Coordinator" shall be the person appointed by the City
Manager.
   (t)   "Recycling Container" shall mean the container furnished by the
resident/businesses/government institution/waste hauler for the express purpose
of storing recyclables for collection by the City Public Works Department or
the recycling contractor.
   (u)   "Resident" shall mean any human being residing within the City on a
temporary or permanent basis, but excluding persons residing in hotels, motels
or similar type establishment.
   (v)   "Solid Waste" shall mean garbage, refuse, and other discarded
materials resulting from commercial, industrial, institutional, residential,
and community activities.
   (w)   "Source Separate" shall mean to separate recyclable materials from the
solid waste stream at the point of waste generation i.e. household, business,
institution, etc.
   (x)    "White Goods" shall mean any household or business appliances made of
metal components such as refrigerators, washing machines, clothes dryers, etc.
   (y)   "Yard Waste" shall include leaves, tree trimmings, brush, grass
clippings, and garden residue. (Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.05  ESTABLISHMENT OF CURBSIDE PROGRAM.
   It shall be mandatory for all persons and entities to separate those
recyclable materials herein specified from all other solid waste in accordance
with the provision of Section
955.07. The City Council shall designate a schedule and plan for curbside
collection of recyclable materials.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.06 COLLECTION STANDARDS.
   (a)    Collection of recyclable materials pursuant to this section shall be
made every two weeks except in cases where the collection day falls upon a
designated holiday. Collection shall occur in accordance with a schedule
publicly advertised by the office of the City Manager. There shall be no
collections or pickup of recycled materials on scheduled holidays that fall on
any collection day. The hours of recyclable collections shall be from 6:00 a.m.
until dusk and shall apply to public and private collectors.
   (b)   All residents of the City shall source separate all designated
recyclables and place them at designated pickup points in the manner described
in Section
955.07 and on the dates specified for collection.
   (c)   All commercial and institutional establishments that currently utilize
the existing curbside refuse collection program of the City are required to
separate the designated recyclables. Those commercial and industrial
establishments who contract privately and individually for recycling/refuse
collection are required to recycle materials as designated by this article and
report tonnages to the office of the City Manager. All private haulers who have
contracts with residential/business/institutional establishments are required
to provide accurate tonnages as to the type and weight of material recycled
annually on the forms provided by the City by the dates stipulated on the
reporting form. All commercial or institutional establishments that do not
utilize the City collection services to recycle are required to provide
accurate tonnages as the type and weight of materials recycled annually on
forms provided by the City.
   (d)   Designated recyclables for the curbside program established pursuant
to this section shall consist of the following materials: newspaper; cans;
aluminum foil; aluminum pans; glass; plastics; mixed paper; office paper;
cardboard; yard waste; and/or other materials. These materials shall be
required to be source separated in separate rigid containers.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.07 SOURCE SEPARATION AND COLLECTION OF DESIGNATED RECYCLABLES .
   All recyclables placed at the curbside shall be prepared for collection in
accordance with the following:
   (a)   All newspaper shall be tied with cord in bundles not exceeding thirty-
five (35) pounds in weight or exceeding one (1) foot in thickness, and kept dry
and be placed at the curbside.
   (b)   Cardboard shall be flattened and tied with cord in bundles not
exceeding thirty-five (35) pounds in weight and dimensions not exceeding three
(3) feet by one (1) foot by three (3) feet and be placed at the curbside.
   (c)   Glass containers shall have caps and lids removed and shall be sorted
by color (clear, green and brown) and placed in rigid open top containers
unless otherwise directed by the City Council.
   (d)   Glass, cans, foil, and plastics shall be rinsed free of contaminants.
   (e)   Aluminum cans, cans, bi-metal, aluminum foil, and aluminum pans shall
be put in a co-mingled rigid container and placed at the curbside.
   (f)   Plastic shall be put in a separate rigid container and placed at the
curbside.
   (g)   Only rigid containers designated by the Public Works Superintendent
shall be utilized for curbside recyclable material collection.
   (h)   No material shall be placed at the curbside earlier than 5:00 p.m. the
evening of the day preceding a scheduled collection day. Material must be
placed at the curbside by 6:00 a.m. on the scheduled collection day. The
bundled newspaper, bundled cardboard, and the co-mingled containers of glass
and cans, and the container of plastics shall be placed at the curbside for
collection adjacent to one another and clearly separated from all other
containers of solid waste.
   (i)   No container shall weigh more than thirty-five pounds when placed at
the curb for collection. (Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.08 ESTABLISHMENT OF LEAF AND YARD WASTE FACILITY.
   A "Leaf and Yard Waste Recycling Facility" will be established for the
processing of leaves and yard waste, including tree trimmings, brush, garden
residue, and grass clippings.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.09 MANDATORY SOURCE SEPARATION OF LEAVES AND YARD WASTE.
   (a)   No person shall dispose of leaves, arrange for the disposal of leaves,
or cause leaves to be disposed at any solid waste facility other than a
composting facility.
   (b)   All persons gathering leaves and grass clippings and served by the
City Sanitation Department shall source separate leaves and yard waste and
place it for collection at the times and in the manner heretofore or hereafter
prescribed by the City Council.
   (c)   Nothing herein shall require any person to gather leaves or prevent
any person from utilizing leaves for compost, mulch, or other agricultural,
horticultural, silvicultural, gardening, or landscaping purposes.
   (d)   Residents/businesses/government institutions within the City shall not
be allowed to chemically treat their grass with poisonous chemicals or
pesticides.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.10 MANDATORY COMMERCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL SOURCE-SEPARATION PROGRAM.
   (a)    All persons within the City not served by the City Curbside Recycling
Program shall source separate and arrange for the collection for recycling of
all designated recyclables upon adoption of this article.
   (b)   Designated recyclables for the mandatory commercial and institutional
source-separation program shall consist of the following materials:
      (1)   Glass containers, cans, plastics.
      (2)   Newspapers
      (3)   High-Grade Office Paper shall include paper items gathered by
offices and/or commercial entities. This may include white computer paper,
white copier paper, white typing paper, white letterhead paper, white note pad
paper, and other similar office paper.
      (4)   Corrugated cardboard.
      (5)   Aluminum
      (6)   Other recyclable materials as designated by the City Council at all
times thirty (30) days after said designation and publication of notice in a
newspaper of general circulation within the City.
   (c)   The arrangement for collection of designated recyclables for
disposition hereunder shall be the responsibility of the person who generates
the recyclables ("generator") or the person contractually obligated to the
generator to arrange for collection and disposal of its solid waste. The
location of any business or institution within the City limits will be the
determining factor for the recyclable collection schedules established by the
City Manager.
   (d)   For the purpose of reporting as required by the West Virginia
Department of Natural Resources, all commercial or institutional establishments
must submit tonnage amounts and types of recyclables to the office of the City
Manager on a form provided by the City of Martinsburg for such purposes,
annually, or as often as deemed necessary by the City Council. Reports for the
preceding year shall be due to the office of the City Manager on the dates
shown on the forms supplied by the City.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.11 PROHIBITED ACTS.
   It shall be unlawful for:
   (a)   Any person other than the City or the designated Contractor to collect
any designated recyclable material which has been placed at the pickup point
for collection or within a recycling drop-off pursuant to this article.
   (b)   Any person to violate or to cause or to assist in the violation of any
provision of this article or any provision of the West Virginia Recycling Act
concerning recycling.
   (c)   Any person to place or to cause to be placed any material other than a
designated recyclable in or near a recycling designated drop-off unless it is
the prescribed day and time and unless an attendant designated by the
Department of Public Works Superintendent is on duty.
   (d)   Any person to hinder, to obstruct, to prevent, or to interfere with
the City Recycling Program or its personnel or designated Contractor in the
performance of any duty under this article or in the enforcement of this
article.
   (e)   Recyclable materials that have been scattered or spilled from
containers or bundles other than the negligence of the City or the recycling
contractor shall be replaced in the proper container promptly by the property
owner.
      (Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.12 NON-COLLECTION OF SOLID WASTE CONTAMINATED BY DESIGNATED RECYCLABLES.
   The City Manager, the Recycling Coordinator, or the designated contractor
collecting solid waste generated within the City may refuse to collect solid
waste from any person. The City may refuse to collect solid waste from any
person who has clearly failed to source separate recyclables designated under
an applicable section of this article.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.13 SCAVENGERS .
   Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, any resident of the City
may not donate or sell any recyclable to any other person, whether operating
for a profit or not for profit. From the time of its placement at the curb by
any person or entity of any mandated recyclable matter for collection by the
City such material shall become the property of the City and it shall be a
violation of this article for any person, scavenger, firm or entity to tamper
with, take. remove or otherwise convert to his or its own use in any way. Any
person found guilty of violating the provision of this section shall be deemed
guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be fined as stipulated
in the penalty provision of Section 955.99. (Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
   955.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever fails to comply with any provision of this article, shall upon
conviction be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) per day and costs of prosecution, and in default of
payment thereof, shall be imprisoned not more than thirty (30) days. Each
continuing day of violation of this article shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 93-17. Passed 8-3-93.)
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF MARTINSBURG
PART ELEVEN - HEALTH AND SANITATION CODE
Art.
1101. Nuisances.
 
 
 
ARTICLE 1101
Nuisances
1101.01    Public nuisance defined.
1101.02    Nuisances affecting health.
1101.03    Nuisances affecting morals.
1101.04    Nuisances affecting peace and safety.
1101.05   Depositing material in Tuscarora Creek.
1101.06   Complaints; notice.
1101.07    Hearing before Council.
1101.08    Responsibility of owners, lessees, tenants.
1101.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to abate - see W.Va. Code 8-12-5(23)
      Abatement of nuisances - see W.Va. Code 16-3-6
   1101.01 PUBLIC NUISANCE DEFINED.
   For the purpose of this article, a public nuisance shall be taken to mean a
thing or act, committed or permitted, failure to act, occupation or use of
property which:
   (a)   Shall annoy, injure or endanger the safety, health, comfort or repose
of any number of persons;
   (b)   Shall offend the public decency;
   (c)   Shall unlawfully interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or
render dangerous for passage, any public park, public playground, street, alley
or highway; or,
   (d)   Shall in any way render any number of persons insecure in life or in
the use and enjoyment of their property.
      (1965 Code Sec. 21-1.)
   1101.02  NUISANCES AFFECTING HEALTH.
   The following are hereby declared to be public nuisances affecting health:
   (a)    All decayed or unwholesome food offered for sale to the public, or
kept or maintained so as to be obnoxious.
   (b)    All diseased animals running at large.
   (c)    All ponds, pools of water, or vessels holding stagnant water in which
mosquitoes can breed.
   (d)    Carcasses of animals not buried or otherwise disposed of in a
sanitary manner within eighteen hours after death.
   (e)    Accumulation of manure or rubbish which are breeding places for
flies, mosquitoes or vermin.
   (f)    Privy vaults and garbage cans which are not fly tight.
   (g)    All noxious weeds and other rank growth of vegetation upon public or
private property.
   (h)    All public exposure of persons having contagious disease.
   (i)    All other acts, omission of acts, occupations and use of property
which are in fact a menace or detriment to the public health.
(1965 Code Sec. 21-2)
   1101.03  NUISANCES AFFECTING MORALS.
   The following are hereby declared to be public nuisances affecting public
morals and decency:
   (a)    All gambling devices, slot machines and punchboards, not permitted by
State statute.
   (b)    All houses, apartments, tenements, or any part or parts thereof, kept
for the purpose of prostitution or promiscuous sexual intercourse and houses of
ill fame and bawdy houses.
   (c)    All places where intoxicating liquors are manufactured, sold,
bartered or given away in violation of law, or where persons are permitted to
resort for the purpose of drinking intoxicating liquors kept for sale, barter
or distribution in violation of law, and all liquors, bottles, kegs, pumps,
bars and other property kept at and used for maintaining such a place.
   (d)    Any vehicle used for any immoral or illegal purpose.
   (e)    All indecent or obscene pictures, books, pamphlets, magazines and
newspapers.
   (f)    Betting, bookmaking, selling baseball pools, race horse pools, and
all arappa tus used in such connection.
   (g)    Gambling houses and all poolrooms where minors under the age of
eighteen years are permitted to enter and are permitted to loaf and loiter
therein; where punchboards, slot machines, race horse pools, baseball pools or
any other scheme, device or apparatus is kept and promoted which constitutes a
game of chance, gambling device or any other scheme by whatsoever name known
which is classed as and is defined by state statute as a game of chance.
      (1965 Code Sec. 21-3.)
   1101.04 NUISANCES AFFECTING PEACE AND SAFETY.
   The following are declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and
safety:
   (a)    All snow and ice not removed from public sidewalks in accordance with
rules and regulations promulgated by the City Manager and approved by Council.
   (b)    All limbs of trees which project over a sidewalk or street and which
are less than eight feet above the surface of such public sidewalk or ten feet
above the surface of such street.
   (c)    All buildings, walks or other structures which have been damaged by
fire, decay or otherwise, and which are so situated as to endanger the safety
of the public.
   (d)    All explosives, flammable liquids and other dangerous substances
stored in any manner or in any amount other than that provided by this Code or
other ordinance of the City.
   (e)    All use or display of fireworks, except as provided by this Code or
other ordinance of the City.
   (f)    All loud or unusual noises, either made or permitted to be made or
condoned, and annoying vibrations, which offend the peace and quiet of persons
of ordinary sensibilities.
   (g)    Obstructions and excavations affecting the ordinary use by the
public, of streets, alleys and sidewalks, or public grounds, except under such
conditions as are provided by this Code or other ordinance of the City.
   (h)    All hanging signs, awnings and other similar structures over the
streets or sidewalks so situated or constructed as to endanger public safety.
   (i)    The allowing of rainwater, ice or snow to fall from any building or
structure upon any street or sidewalk or to flow across any sidewalk.
   (j)    All barbed-wire fences which are located within three feet of any
public sidewalk or thoroughfare.
   (k)    The distribution of handbills, except as provided by this Code and
other ordinance of the City.
   (l)    All abandoned or discarded items of personal property, junk or
collection of equipment exposed to public view, including automobiles,
furniture, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, cans, boxes and containers.
      (Passed 5-28-81.)
   1101.05  DEPOSITING MATERIAL IN TUSCARORA CREEK.
   (a)    No person shall deposit or throw or cause to be deposited or thrown
any offal from any slaughterhouse or any other building or any dead animals or
fowl or other deleterious material into Tuscarora Creek or its tributaries
within the corporate limits of the City.
   (b)    Upon conviction of a violation of any provision of the first
paragraph of this section, the person so convicted shall have a reasonable time
to remove the offal or dead animal or fowl or other deleterious material
involved in the conviction, within the discretion of the Chief of Police, but
such time shall not exceed five (5) days.
(1965 Code Sec. 22-49.)
   1101.06 COMPLAINTS; NOTICE.
   (a)    The Police Chief, any police officer, the Chief of the Fire
Department, any member of the Fire Department, the City Health Officer, or any
member of the Health Department, or any bona fide citizen residing in the City
may file under oath a complaint against any person maintaining or harboring any
nuisance.
   (b)    If such complaint is filed by a citizen other than by some one of the
City officials above designated, such complaint may be laid before Council at
its next regular or special session or meeting, and if Council directs, the
City Recorder shall issue notice to be served upon the person charged with
maintaining or harboring such nuisance, requiring him to appear before Council,
at a designated time, and to show cause, if any he can, why such nuisance
should not be abated. Such notice shall be served, as other legal notices are
served, on the owner, lessee, agent, manager in charge, or any servant or
employee in charge or control of the premises where the nuisance in question is
alleged to exist, at least five days prior to the time set therein for the
hearing before Council.
   (c)    If the complaint is filed by any City official above named, the City
Recorder shall forthwith issue such notice without the necessity of referring
the complaint to Council.
(1965 Code Sec. 21-5.)
   1101.07  HEARING BEFORE COUNCIL.
   Pursuant to notice, Council shall conduct a hearing pursuant to this
article, at which hearing both the complainant and the person so charged with
maintaining such nuisance, together with such witnesses as they may produce
shall be fully heard. Upon such hearing a continuance for proper cause shown
may be granted at the instance of either party. If upon the hearing of the
matter Council by majority vote of the members present constituting a quorum
thereof shall determine that such nuisance exists as charged in the complaint,
it shall provide by resolution for its abatement as follows:
   (a)    If such nuisance be in a place of business or other establishment for
the conduct of which the City has issued a license, then such license may be
revoked.
   (b)    If the nuisance found to exist be that of conducting a house of ill
fame bawdy house, house of prostitution, gambling house, or place for the
handling, sale or other disposition of intoxicating liquors contrary to the
statutes of the state or the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the
City,. the. resolution of Council may authorize and direct the City Attorney to
tutrtnms on behalf of the City a suit in equity in the proper form for the
abatement of such nuisance and the closing of such premises as provided by
statute.
   (c)    If any nuisance be found to exist other than those specially
enumerated in subsections (a) and (b) hereof, and the provisions of this Code
and other ordinances of the City do not provide for its abatement Council may
authorize the issuance of a warrant before the Mayor or, upon the complamt of
any official of the City, or any bona fide resident, filed before the Mayor,
prosecution shall immediately be had of any person shown to be maintaining or
harboring such nuisance.
      (1965 Code Sec. 21-6.)
   1101.08 RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS. LESSEES. TENANTS.
   (a)    Any person having control over any premises upon or in which a
nuisance is maintained or harbored in violation of this article whether he be
the owner, lessee, sublessee, tenant, occupant or the agent or manager in
charge for any such owner, lessee, sublessee, tenant or occupant thereof, shall
be subject to the provisions of this article and may be proceeded against in
all respects as fully as is provided in the foregoing provisions of this
article with reference to the occupant of such premises.
   (b)    Prosecutions under this article shall not be deemed to be exclusive,
but shall in addition to all other penalties provided by any other provision of
this Code or other ordinance of the City authorizing the prosecution and
conviction for any violation of the provisions of this Code or other ordinances
of the City, even though the result of the offense charged would be the setting
up, maintaining or harboring of a nuisance and within the purview of this
article.
(1965 Code Sec. 21-7.)
   1101.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who shall knowingly cause or create any public nuisance or permit
any public nuisance to be created or to be placed upon or to remain upon any
premises owned or occupied by him, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall,
in addition to all other penalties provided for in this article or any other
provision of this Code or ordinance of the City, be punished as provided in
Section
101.99, and each day a nuisance is maintained or harbored shall constitute a
separate offense and may be proceeded against by separate prosecution until
such nuisance is abated.
(1965 Code Sec. 21-8.)

PART THIRTEEN - PLANNING AND ZONING CODE
